content: I've increased the difficulty from Medium to Hard in view of the low community success ratio (solved by 570 out of 4399, or 12.96%).

So far I haven't actually changed any test cases, but I noticed that (what is now) the last test case is the only one where:
* The where clause compares numerical instead of string values.
* The order by clause orders by string instead of numeric values.
* The order by clause orders by a column that is not selected.

Ideally these would all be included, but they're not covered in the validators. Worse, the sort order in this test is ineffective as there's only a single row to output. It's too late to fix this by extending the tests and validators. Therefore, I would like to change the last test case to more closely mirror its validator. This will only simplify the problem. In particular, I'd like to use:

SELECT Rooms, Regionname FROM Housing WHERE Suburb = HeidelbergHeights ORDER BY Rooms DESC

Changed difficulty to Medium and removed reference to difficulty in the statement.
Rewrote introductory line, removing "Puzzle is meant to be a quick intro to SQL. Nothing too wild."
Negated this statement, as they are not tested for: "Multiple conditions can be concatenated with {{AND}}, {{OR}}."
Clarified numerical values in statement and added to constraints.
Removed generic topic link to W3Schools.
Matched inputs and stub generator with some revision in statement and other minor formatting.
Moved last test case into third position since it's simpler. Renamed "Slightly bigger table" to "Slightly more advanced".
Corrected misleading validator names to match name of test case.
Spelled out "ascending" and "descending". Applied consistent casing thruout.
Changed write statement to two lines, removing superfluous instruction about indexes.
I've edited the order of the input entries in "ORDER BY DESC" test case based on the comment on the forum: https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-parse-sql-queries/190119/22

It's a bit unfortunate that the table name is to be extracted from the SQL query. It's metadata that's also very closely related to the actual table contents, and a likely hindrance to expanding the format to multiple tables later on.

(not to mention it foils my implementation plan)

Mind if I add them?
The statement says that "Multiple conditions can be concatenated with AND, OR" but I don't see this implemented in the solution or in any test cases. Should this line be removed?
I edited the "Following * Lines" in Input and Output.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good practise for parsing basic SQL statements. Glad it doesn't include INNER JOINs.

Nice contribution Antisquid if i were 20 level i approved the contribution but i am not 2 guys approved the contribution it approved some time later
:smile:

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is very fun to solve and gives an idea of what SQL is, which is great. Well done :-) !
The statement is clear and there is fair enough tests.
Your latest legend certification is on its way ;-) !

The sort of tests 5 (Titanic Table) and validator 5 (Alternate Keys) are not stable, i.e. order of element that are ‚Äúequal‚Äù is not conserved. Perhaps the pandas solution you used falls back to another column when two lines got equal value on the sorted column‚Ä¶

In Titanic Talbe, the output contains
‚Ä¶
Andrews 39 112050
Taussig 39 110413
‚Ä¶
Gee 47 111320
Porter 47 110465
‚Ä¶
but in the input, Taussig is before Andrews, and Porter is before Gee.
It seems panda has sorted over the name when ages were equals.

In Alternate Keys, there is 4 stable breaking :
‚Ä¶
Gee 47 111320
Porter 47 110465
‚Ä¶
Butt 45 113050
Romaine 45 111428
‚Ä¶
Carrau 28 113059
Bjornstrom-Steffansson 28 110564
‚Ä¶
Hippach 16 111361
Maioni 16 110152
‚Ä¶

There is a typo for Stead entry, the fare is different between input and output :
 253 0 1 Stead male 62 0 0 11351
Stead 62 113514

I think it would be better to have a stable sort, or at least specify in the statement that in case of a tie, you have to sort on another column (the first one?), but that would make the puzzle much more difficult to solve‚Ä¶ and what to do if there is a tie, again!?
Furthermore, sorts are stable by default, that the case of sorted in Python :
https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#sorted
and also the case of sort in Perl (so my solution does not pass test/validator 5 :-/ !)

Here is my solution in Perl (that does not pass test/validator 5):
https://gist.github.com/LaurentValade/4d14e116783fb2baef59eff134cec484
sorry about its uglyness, I wrote it quickly.

Very nice puzzle, the statement is well written and there is fair enough tests :-).
I am trying to solve it, then I will approve it.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A great way to understand simple queries and be able to replicate them yourself. Loved it.

Hi, please refresh the page or something. I have meanwhile edited those values by adding 0.1 to some of the ages to make them different. For example:
 
Name Age Ticket
Maioni 16 110152
Hippach 16.1 111361

Basically the sort function is quicksort and it's quite messy. Normally there would be more than one criteria for sorting or if I sort by one value order wouldn't matter.
Problem with validators however is that order matters. It's fixed.

Anyways thanks for trying out the puzzle.
Thanks. Much appreciated!
Yeah, and I heard that the second one is handsome and very smart :-D !

Not sure what this about. Is that really what i initially wrote??

Thanks i guess?

See next sentence:
"Since this is an easy puzzle the only condition you need to check for is if the values are equal."

This is an intro. It's meant to give you a quick overview of queries.
What do you want to add exactly?
Done.

Good job on improving the puzzle.

There are still a few issues that we should / may address:

Constraints
* [[columns]] isn't defined anywhere. My suggestion is to replace it with "the number of columns in the initial (unfiltered) table" (to distinguish it from the output (filtered) table).

* The first constraint is violated in the second pair of cases (the input contains "3MichelineStarFries" / "3Fries"). I think the constraint may be removed and that should not cause any confusion.

Terms
* (optional) Different terms may be standardised.
  ‚Ä¢ Goal section: "column_name"
  ‚Ä¢ Input section: "table header" and "title"
  ‚Ä¢ Output section: "header" and "column titles"
  ‚Ä¢ Stub generator: "tableHeader" and "columnTitles"
Should be done now. Went with [[columnName#]] or [[column names]] for the latter.
Great, looks good to me. Many thanks.

The incorrect constraint I added was based on a comment by @pardouin which I must have misinterpreted and didn't thoroughly check. While it's no longer needed or listed, neither is there a clear or pressing need to start a string value with "3". The focus of the puzzle is parsing the query, not this input edge case. So I'm eliminating it.

Hmmm, actually I don't see that as an edge case nor a need to eliminate it. I mean, yeah, that's covered in only one pair of cases, but actually it's good that it enforces the need to check carefully to determine whether a column is of the variable type of number or string, beyond just checking the first character of the value of a field.

In Python, it's just:

try:
    field = float(field)
    # now we know the field is of the number type
except:
    pass
    # now we know the field is of the string type

So, I'd rather those cases be restored.

They don't even matter because they're not the first record of the initial table. By applying the third constraint, we can determine the variable type of a column by checking the first row of the table only.
You're right, it shouldn't even matter.

I've just updated the last test with an additional record:
HeidelbergHeightsWest 1 Banyule EasternMetropolitan

I added this because a player passed the test but failed the validator after using a startsWith check instead of an exact match.
The table name, on a separate line, before n or before the header row. (in a way that it could easily be multiplied later when joins come into play)
I intentionally left that out to keep inputs and operations to a minimum for this easy puzzle. Can adapt it for harder SQL puzzles.

Also i don't hold copy rights over SQL puzzles. Maybe you can do better puzzles instead sad face emote. :)

Everyone is waiting for your trolls vs castles to be released btw. People clearly love it.
People loving it is unfortunately not the same thing as ‚Äúit should be released.‚Äù  Pretty far from it.
You wrote ¬´ Following n‚àí1 lines ¬ª.

I remember the n-1. Forgot to change it I guess.

Initially i wanted to give the entire table in the input including the headers. It went through some changes to make it simpler since it's an easy puzzle.

You are welcome, it was very fun to solve :-).

Make all ages differents was indeed a solution to the stability problem; and it was the simple one (and the safest), so the best one !

I just retry, and my solution pass every tests and validators.
